chapter.title: Declarative Exception Mapping
chapter.para: The JAX-RS specification comes with Exception Mapping Providers as standard a mechanism for treating Java exceptions. This approach works fine for complex cases, however, the exception handling logic is often trivial and implementing Exception Mapper Providers is an overkill. In these situations, declarative approach is more appropriate. Seam RESTEasy allows exception types to be bound to HTTP responses declaratively.
For each exception type, it is possible to specify the status code of the HTTP response and an error message.

example.title: HTTP response
example.programlisting:
HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found Content-Type: application/xml Content-Length: 123
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?> <error> <message>Requested resource does not exist.</message> </error>

chapter.para: Furthermore, EL expressions can be used in message templates to provide dynamic and more descriptive error messages.

example.title: Exception mapping configuration in seam-beans.xml
example.programlisting: <resteasy:ExceptionMapping exceptionType="javax.persistence.NoResultException" statusCode="404"> <resteasy:message>Requested resource with id #{pathParameters['id']} does not exist.</resteasy:message> </resteasy:ExceptionMapping>

chapter.para: The error message is marshalled within a JAXB object. As a result, the error message is available in multiple media formats. The most commonly used formats are XML and JSON. RESTEasy provides media providers for both these formats. In addition, the error message is also available as a plain text.
